metadata.Name: HellaSwag
metadata.Description: HellaSwag is a dataset for commonsense natural language inference, created using adversarial filtering to generate challenging machine-generated wrong answers.
metadata.Paper Title: HellaSwag: Can a Machine Really Finish Your Sentence?
metadata.Venue Title: Proceedings of the 2018 Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing (EMNLP)
Affiliations: Paul G. Allen School of Computer Science & Engineering, University of Washington
metadata.Abstract: A woman is outside with a bucket and a dog. The dog is running around trying to avoid a bath. She... A. rinses the bucket off with soap and blow dry the dog’s head. Recent work by Zellers et al. (2018) introduced a new task of commonsense natural language inference: given an event description such as “A woman sits at a piano,” a machine must select the most likely followup: “She sets her fingers on the keys.” With the introduction of BERT (Devlin et al., 2018), near-human level performance was reached. However, this paper shows that commonsense inference remains difficult for even state-of-the-art models, by presenting HellaSwag, a new challenge dataset.
